isis.stitle: DT/DTI-466 A and B Series DT/DTI/DTA-466 C Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1993) - DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS - DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS PROCEDURES FOR.. - ...EXCESSIVE EXHAUST SMOKE

step1.para: Excessive visual smoke can occur under two separate general conditions:

Excessive visual exhaust smoke can be caused by improper operation of the vehicle. For example, the driver must keep the engine speed within the specified rpm range for the transmission and rear axle ratio.
Diagnosis of this problem is critical.

step2.para: Check the air induction system and air cleaner restriction.
Inspect the turbocharger for signs of lube oil leakage in the compressor housing.
Inspect the cooling system; over cooling can cause blue smoke.
Excessive lube oil consumption can cause blue smoke.
Constant gray smoke can be caused by poor injection nozzle condition or the air induction system. Refer to Section 5 for test procedures.
BLACK SMOKE - must be immediately corrected. All areas of appropriate "PROBLEM ANALYSIS GUIDE" (CGED-390-2 and CGED-365- *) must be investigated to determine the cause.

step1.para: If the problem cannot be resolved by analysis, remove the injection pump for a test stand analysis.

step2.para: These conditions result in misfiring with a warm engine.

step1.para: In general, any excess smoke problem can be resolved by following the procedures in the appropriate "PERFORMANCE ANALYSIS GUIDE".
